review.title: A Joint Framework for Argumentative Text Analysis Incorporating Domain Knowledge
review.abstract: For argumentation mining, there are several sub-tasks such as argumentation component type classification, relation classification. Existing research tends to solve such sub-tasks separately, but ignore the close relation between them. In this paper, we present a joint framework incorporating logical relation between sub-tasks to improve the performance of argumentation structure generation. We design an objective function to combine the predictions from individual models for each sub-task and solve the problem with some constraints constructed from background knowledge. We evaluate our proposed model on two public corpora and the experiment results show that our model can outperform the baseline that uses a separate model significantly for each sub-task. Our model also shows advantages on component-related sub-tasks compared to a state-of-the-art joint model based on the evidence graph.

sections.heading: 3 Framework of ILP-based Joint Model
sections.text: The overall framework of our common reasoning mining model is in Figure 2. For an argumentative text unit, we first use several separate models to predict the results for each subtask. Our common model then takes the probability values from each model as input for the objective function. We also define constraints based on the annotation scheme of the target corpus.

To evaluate our proposed common model, we use two public corporas, consisting of microtext (Peldszus and Stede, 2015a) and compelling papers (Stab and Gurevych, 2014a). In the first corpus, all texts are generated for research purposes in a controlled environment. It ensures the tree structure of arguments in the input text unit. In the second corpus, all documents are student papers collected on an online learning platform. Thus, it contains noise. With different annotation schemes, these two corporas have different sub-task settings. We design objective functions and construct corresponding constraints for each corpus.

sections.heading: 4 Joint Model for Microtext
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Microtext Corpus
sections.text: The corpus of "micro-texts" comes from Peldszus and Stede (2015a). The data set contains 112 text units with 576 ADUs; 23 text units are written by the authors, while the rest are generated by instructed users in a controlled environment; the corpus is commented according to a scheme that represents an argumentation structure at segment level (Freeman, 1991); the notes include three ADU type designations; a central claim (CC if it is a central claim); a role (RO, supporter or opponent); a function (FU, support, attack and none); and a caption (AT if there is a binding relationship between a pair of ADUs). A text unit in this corpus can be shown in Figure 1.This corpus has the following properties: (1) The length of each text is about 5 ADUs. (2) A segment explicitly indicates the central claim. (3) Each segment is argumentative.

sections.heading: 4.2 ILP-based Joint Model
sections.text: There are four sub-tasks designed in this corpus based on its annotation scheme, including the central claim definition (cc), role identification (ro), function classification (fu) and appendix classification (at). Our common model takes as input the probability values predicted by the individual classifiers for each sub-task and collectively generates the final prediction (attaPi + eiATTi + giNONEi). To view all sub-tasks at the same time, we aim to maximize the following objective function: when the four different components each correspond to four sub-tasks: CCi stands for the probability that segment i is a central claim; ROi stands for the probability that segment i has a different role; SUPi, ATTi and NONEi for the probability that the segment is variable.

sections.heading: 4.3 Results
sections.text: We implemented the approach of (Peldszus and Stede, 2015b) for each sub-task. For the sub-task cc, ro and at, we trained binary classifiers, while a three-way classifier was used for fu. 10-fold cross-validation. We reported F-1 score for each sub-task and its macro-F1. We compared three approaches to this corpus. - Separately: the basic approach of (Peldszus and Stede, 2015b), which we newly implemented. - MST: We implemented the evidence-graph-based approach of (Peldszus and Stede, 2015b). This approach first generates a fully connected multigraph across all segments. Subsequently, the prediction truths from different sub-tasks are combined as edge weights. Finally, MST is used to decode the graph and generate a tree structure as an argumentation structure.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Overall Experiment Results
sections.text: Table 2 shows results based on the microtext corpus. MST and ILP use the same weighting 2 for sub-task combination.1We achieved similar results for all sub-tasks except function classification. 2We also investigated optimizing weighting for each sub-task based on the definition of a 10x cross-validation. Both common models (MST and ILP) can improve performance via separate baseline for all sub-tasks (except MST for Fu), and the improvements are significant 3 in terms of macro-F1. This indicates that the common prediction of sub-tasks reduces the performance of each individual task for reasoning. Compared to MST, our ILP approach achieves equal or better results for all sub-tasks (except MST for all sub-tasks).

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Discussion
sections.text: In order to show the contribution of each sub-task to the predictions of the other sub-tasks, we simulate better individual classification results and examine their impact. We use the strategy proposed in this experiment (Peldszus and Stede, 2015b). We artificially improved the classification result of a sub-task by overwriting a percentage of its predictions with the basic truth. Overwritten samples are randomly selected and the selection process is higher than the original base classifier, regardless of whether the base classifier has already chosen the correct label. The simulation result can be seen in Figure 3. The figure shows the F score on the Y-axis for all sub-tasks when the improvement percentage on the top of the base classifier for a task is varied (x-axis). Each sub-figure shows the simulation results in improving the relevant task. As we can see, the function classification is improved by better use of a role classification.

sections.heading: 5 Joint Model for Student Essays
sections.text: The corpus of the microtext (Peldszus and Stede, 2015b) shows the effectiveness of the common models for argumentation mining, including the evidence graph-based method and our ILP-based approach. However, the corpus is created for research purposes and follows some limited rules (e.g. a central claim, an arrow for non-central claims, etc.) from which the common models could benefit. To demonstrate the flexibility of our ILP-based approach to argumentation mining, we applied our ILP-based model to another corpus (Rod and Gurevych, 2014a) consisting of student papers.

sections.heading: 5.1 Student Essays Corpus
sections.text: This corpus has been shown to be a complete student essay, but only in a few cases does it require the support of individual paragraphs. Thus, we treat each paragraph as a single entity that follows (Staff and Gurevych, 2014b). The original corpus contains 416 paragraphs. In the original version of the corpus, there are two sub-tasks, namely component classification and identification. The first aims to identify a target component as an important claim, and the second comprises 416 paragraphs.

sections.heading: 5.2 ILP-based Joint Model
sections.text: There are two subtasks in this corpus based on its annotation scheme, including the component classification q (comp) and the relationship classification (rel). Our ILP model takes the output of the individual models for the two subtasks as input and aims to generate results for both tasks in a way of mutual reinforcement. Suppose there are N argumentative components in a target paragraph. We aim to maximize the following objective function: v ² i {aiCi + biPi} + (1 − v): i, j {cijSUPij}, where ai and bi are two binary variables to indicate whether the target component is a claim or a premise.

sections.heading: 5.3 Results
sections.text: We implemented the approach of (Rod and Gurevych, 2014b) for each subtask. For the classification of the components, we used five categories of characteristics, including structural, lexical, syntactical, indicators and contextual. Instead of SVM, we used MaxEntropy for the classification because it shows better results in our implementation. For the classification of the relationships, we also followed the original paper and used MaxEntropy. We used 10-fold cross validation. For both tasks, we trained binary classifiers. We use the probabilities predicted by the two classifiers as input for our ILP model. F-1 score is used as a benchmark. We compared the following three approaches. - Separated: the basic structural approach of (Rod and Gurevych, 2014b) that we use the probabilities predicted by the two classifiers as input for our ILP model.

sections.heading: 5.3.1 Discussion
sections.text: The result of the simulation experiment on this corpus can be seen in Figure 6. As we can see, the performance of the component classification is greatly improved by a better classification of the relationships. However, the effect of a better classification of the components on the identification of the relationships is small. This is because the role of each component can be easily identified. In contrast, even the classification of the components is perfect, the identification of the relationship between them is still difficult. Furthermore, the low performance of the subtask to identify the basic relationship is also important. We also evaluate the effect of different weight combinations in the same way as with the microtext corpus. The result shows that for larger components, the performance of the classification is generally higher; the influence of α on the relation classification is lower. This could be because the base performance for the relation classifier is low. Due to the length limit, we did not show an illustration here.The result is in Figure 5. The higher v, the greater the contribution to the common classification, the greater the greater the influence of the common component on the common classification is, the smaller the impact on the common component is on the common component.

sections.heading: 6 Summary and Future Work
sections.text: Our ILP-based approach is superior to the existing graphical model because it can work on all types of data sets without requiring a tree structure as input, and because it can use more common information represented by constraints, especially for component-based tasks. There are two interesting directions for future research. First, we will look at other types of argumentative texts that have more noise and an even more complicated argumentation structure, such as posts from online discussion forums. Second, we will integrate our argumentation-mining framework for automatic student essay evaluation.

Palau and Moens (2011) used a hand-written context-free grammar to predict argumentation trees on legal documents. Kirchner et al. (2015) presented an annotation study for fine-grained analysis of argumentation structures in scientific publications. For data-driven approaches, Lawrence et al. (2014) constructed tree structures on philosophical texts using unsupervised methods based on topical distance between segments. Stab and Gurevych (2014b) presented a supervised approach for student essays. Peldszus and Stede (2015b) aimed to identify the attachment relation between ADUs on a microtext corpus. Joint model for argumentation mining: Although there are several approaches for different subtasks in argumentation mining, researchers rarely consider to solve sub-tasks in unified way. Stab and Gurevych (2014b) explored to directly use the prediction results of ADU type classification as features for the task of relation classification, however, without considering logical relation between these two tasks, the effect was marginal. Peldszus and Stede (2015b) tackled four argumentation mining tasks including three ADU type classification tasks and the task of relation identification.
The corpus is annotated according to a scheme representing segment-level argumentation structure (Freeman, 1991).

metadata.abstractText: For argumentation mining, there are several sub-tasks such as argumentation component type classification, relation classification. Existing research tends to solve such sub-tasks separately, but ignore the close relation between them. In this paper, we present a joint framework incorporating logical relation between sub-tasks to improve the performance of argumentation structure generation. We design an objective function to combine the predictions from individual models for each sub-task and solve the problem with some constraints constructed from background knowledge. We evaluate our proposed model on two public corpora and the experiment results show that our model can outperform the baseline that uses a separate model significantly for each sub-task. Our model also shows advantages on component-related sub-tasks compared to a state-of-the-art joint model based on the evidence graph.
